16.1 Best-Suited Categories: Healthcare services that meet real needs: home health, ABA therapy, PT or OT or speech therapy, end-of-life support and transport, dermatology, audiology, optometry  — Why it fits: sticky demand, mission-driven work, regulation can be a moat, and Pushkar is deeply interested in healthcare; prefers clinic-based care and a balanced payer mix to lower Medicaid risk  — Example: Pure-play, clinic-based ABA therapy in Phoenix or SoCal: recurring schedules and payer contracts, prefer a balanced payer mix (not heavy at-home Medicaid), strong local demand, and no clinical license needed to own

IT managed services and cybersecurity  — Why it fits: recurring B2B contracts, clear SLAs, and a strong match with Pushkar’s tech and product background  — Example: MSP with endpoint management and help desk: monthly retainers; clear playbook to upsell security and backup. Also fits: hosted PBX/managed voice tied to service contracts; healthcare IT installs paired with MSP support for hospitals (bid-sourced projects with recurring service).

B2B professional services (recurring)  — Why it fits: process and systems oriented, steady cash flow, and easy to layer bolt-ons  — Example: Bookkeeping and tax services: monthly retainers; leverages his systems thinking and analytics

Building and construction trades with maintenance contracts  — Why it fits: steady service revenue, local moat, licensing can create barriers to entry; Arizona climate boosts demand  — Example: HVAC service and light install: twice-yearly maintenance plans; NTE approvals and route density improve margins

Facility and property services  — Why it fits: route-based work, contracted customers, recession resistant  — Example: Commercial janitorial and window cleaning: multi-year contracts; easy to add services like pressure washing and floor care

Childcare and education services  — Why it fits: high willingness to pay from parents, durable need, and expansion via new classrooms or a second site  — Example: Daycare or preschool: waitlists in growth areas; stable monthly tuition
Pet services  — Why it fits: strong recurring spend from owners and multiple service lines  — Example: Grooming and daycare under one roof: membership plans drive repeat visits

Transportation and logistics services  — Why it fits: B2B contracts, operations-focused, scalable through routes and capacity planning  — Example: Courier and freight forwarding: contracted pickups; cross-dock and last-mile growth

Light manufacturing with steady B2B demand  — Why it fits: repeat orders, municipal or enterprise buyers, operational improvements can unlock margin  — Example: Custom or traffic signage: mandated replacement cycles; predictable reorders

Business-facing communications and print  — Why it fits: local moat, repeat B2B orders, upsell opportunities  — Example: Custom signs and banner printing: event and facility needs; easy to add installation and maintenance
16.2 Strategic Opportunities: Specialty outpatient clinics with sticky follow-up  — Why it fits: recurring care and retail add-ons; aligns with healthcare interest  — Example: Audiology and hearing aids or optometry with optical retail

Pediatric therapy centers (OT, PT, speech) near or co-located with ABA  — Why it fits: similar staffing and payer mix; cross-referrals; strengthens a local care footprint  — Example: OT/PT/speech clinic next to an ABA center sharing intake and back office

Med spa focused on injectables and laser services  — Why it fits: injectables have high retention; strong unit economics when well-run  — Example: Injectables-led practice with memberships and pre-paid packages
Fire protection inspection and service  — Why it fits: code-driven recurring inspections; similar cadence to HVAC service plans  — Example: Annual and quarterly inspections with repair upsells

Elevator, gate, and access control service firms  — Why it fits: contracted maintenance, urgent repair premiums, vendor relationships  — Example: Elevator service routes with parts inventory and modernization projects
Mold remediation and environmental services (asbestos, lead)  — Why it fits: urgent, insurance-paid, regulation as moat  — Example: Mold remediation with water mitigation partnerships

Non-emergency medical transport and medical courier  — Why it fits: healthcare adjacency, contracted routes, operations-heavy  — Example: NEMT serving clinics and dialysis centers; steady weekday volume
Home inspections, insulation, and energy efficiency  — Why it fits: steady demand in growth markets; strong add-on to other trades  — Example: Spray foam or attic insulation with home energy audits
Waste and storage niches  — Why it fits: durable demand and simple operations  — Example: Junk removal and self storage in fast-growing Phoenix submarkets

Digital agencies that sell to businesses  — Why it fits: retainers, clear KPIs, and can add AI-enabled services to lift margins  — Example: SEO and web management with monthly care plans and content packages

Niche B2B SaaS or software-enabled service only when priced reasonably and sticky  — Why it fits: leverages product skill set; improve ops in a vertical he will run  — Example: Scheduling or billing software for clinics or MSP tooling with high retention

Healthcare IT integration and installations (hospital systems)  — Why it fits: bridges his MSP/tech skills with healthcare; mix of bid-based installs plus recurring MSP support  — Example: Hardware/software installs for hospital systems with ongoing MSP service for support and maintenance

Managed voice/UCaaS and low-voltage systems  — Why it fits: adjacency to MSP and PBX; recurring seats and support; clear cross-sell for after-hours AI agents  — Example: Hosted PBX with maintenance contracts and AI call handling add-ons

Electrical contractors and solar O&M  — Why it fits: licensing path clarified; recurring inspections and service; Arizona is favorable for solar  — Example: Electrical service with solar O&M contracts and panel/permit upgrade work
16.3 Avoid Categories: Restaurants and food and beverage of all types (restaurants, cafes, bars, food trucks, grocery, liquor and wine)  — Reason: low margins, heavy labor, volatile demand
Most retail stores and consumer shops (apparel, jewelry, furniture, gift, vape, convenience, office furniture, gun stores, etc.)  — Reason: inventory risk and foot traffic dependence

Discretionary entertainment and leisure venues (amusement parks, arcades, escape rooms, cinemas, go-karting, golf courses, nightclubs, theaters, sports teams or facilities)  — Reason: want-not-need spending and weekend-heavy hours
Traditional media outlets dependent on ads or subscriptions (newspapers, periodicals or magazines, radio and television stations)  — Reason: declining audiences and ad risk

Crypto-related businesses and ad or affiliate content sites, dropshipping or FBA ecommerce, mobile apps-only plays  — Reason: platform risk, volatility, and not aligned with his steady, physical-business focus
Algorithm-dependent online businesses reliant on Google search or paid traffic  — Reason: platform/algorithm swings; he does not want the anxiety of traffic risk and was burned by this before
Consumer transportation rentals and taxis; RV dealers  — Reason: asset damage risk, tourism swings, and discretionary demand
Cash-heavy or reputationally sensitive categories (bail bonds, collection agencies, pawn, cash-for-gold)  — Reason: lender and reputational risk
Gas stations  — Reason: thin fuel margins and environmental liability
Tree farms and orchards; garden centers and nurseries  — Reason: climate risk in Arizona and long, seasonal cycles
Pure beauty salon concepts that are mainly cosmetic wants (hair or nail salons, esthetician retail-only)  — Reason: discretionary spend and high churn
Party and event venues or rentals, wedding venues, tanning salons, seminars-only businesses, KDP-only publishing  — Reason: cyclical demand and limited pricing power
Businesses with heavy ongoing working capital needs (big AR/inventory swings, heavy line-of-credit usage)  — Reason: ties up too much cash, needs a big line of credit, and adds too much risk

New-construction-heavy contractors or project-only trades without strong maintenance/backlog  — Reason: high cyclicality; he does not want to tie his personal guarantee to new-construction risk; prefers stable maintenance contracts
